 Aside from tax reserves and fund allocations, tell me the fundamental difference between C corp and 501-3C accounting structures. I've prepared and reviewed both with virtually the same account structure on income statements and balance sheets. Tax filing obviously differs, but both produce financial statements which are audited with identical procedures. Most large C corps have a not-for-profit entity, often a foundation funded or partially funded by the namesake, that reports separately but is always mentioned in annual reports as PR. What would be the difference in a church reporting as a C with a charitable entity? (I'll bet the Catholic Diocese in Portland, OR wishes it had C corp status)

I don't know about all 501c3 organizations because this isn't exactly what determines how accounting is done. However, Not-for-profit organzations tend to have do fund accounting as opposed to your normal accural basis accounting. Fund accounting is kinda like cash-basis..and might as well be. They will be reported as looking similiar to a C corp, having what looks like an income statement and what looks like a balance sheet. Look at the financial statements for the American Diabetes Association. http://www.diabetes.org/uedocuments/ADA2004ConsolidatedFinancialStatements_1.pdf
 
 As you can see they have slightly different names such as the statement of activities. The reason for this is because they really have no revenue to match with an expense (as they have no products). They get revenue from donations and special events or membershipt fees...all of which go into different funds and are treated differently. You will also frequently see "restricted" as well...sometimes for endowments or something along those lines and restricted donations. Then you have conditional revenue too. Sometimes someone will say "I will give you a million bucks once I run across the United States"...a regular C corp reconginzes this as a revenue while a Not-for-profit won't. You can also see a difference in actitives such as "supporting" and "program" which are common among not-for-profit. These are just some differences that jump out off the top of my head.
 
 The reason you can't really seperate it out is because you can match an expense to any kind of revenue. Lets say you have a church that does charity work 50% of the time and preach 50% of the time. They get $100 in donations. The $100 goes to paying for the building with $10 left over. You might say that the expenses for the "charity" are 45 and the chruch preaching is 45. A church can then just say the donation will be 45 for the church preaching and 55 for the charity...you can do this because donations that are not restricted can be sent any way you want. So the church now has 0 income and thus no taxes and the charity who is tax-exempt has a profit which doesn't matter..because they are tax-exempt. It just makes it very difficult to split out charity work in a church. An organization like NARAL might be easier to not make tax-exempt because they don't do much in the ways of charity. I can explain this further if you like but in a sense you would just make NARAL a C corp with foundation (which is kinda what they are being a 501 c 4 organization as well).

 Church receives revenue, in the form of donations, tithes, etc. for services rendered, be it preaching, home visits, missions, etc. no different than any other business. Income is distributed to pay for various operating expenses, including normal taxes, to maintain that service level with any surplus staying on the balance sheet in the form of cash or other assets. If a church wishes to donate to a charity, it does so in the same manner as a taxed business, as a defined operating expense to a separate entity. 
 
 Charity is defined as tangible services, food, clothing, housing, etc., a separate reporting entity. 
 
 Just as with any business, the customer/parishioner determines the allocation, not the church. If $1.00 comes in with no designated split allocation, it all goes to the taxable entity. 
 
 I don't understand your reluctance to treat a church as any other revenue producing entity. Presenting spiritual worship is a service, no different than a laundry or accountant or palm reader. Many taxed businesses collect charitable contributions and direct them to separate, not-for-profit entities, Red Cross for Katrina relief being a prominent example.
